section.title: Compiler Support
section.para: GNU/GCC is available also for Windows OS, via Minimalist GNU for Windows (MinGW)
The libiers10++ Software Package uses the C++11 ISO, which is supported by any version of GNU/GCC later than v4.3 (for a detailed list, see C++0x/C++11 Support in GCC).

important.para:
When compiling against the GNU/GCC compiler the user must set the appropriate flag for using the C++11 ISO. Depending on the version of the compiler, this can either be -std=c++11 (for versions later than v4.6), or -std=c++0x (for versions earlier than v4.6). To see what version of GNU/GCC you use, just type: bash$ g++ --version You should see an output simmilar to the following
g++ (GCC) 4.9.2 20150212 (Red Hat 4.9.2-6) Copyright (C) 2014 Free Software Foundation, Inc. This is free software; see the source for copying conditions. There is NO warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
where the version is clear in the first line (i.e. in this example v4.9.2).

section.title: Quick Guide
section.para:
Follow the next steps to install the Software: Quick Install
If you downloaded the tarball, you first need to uncompress it; bash$ tar xzvf libiers10++-1.0.tar.gz This will create a new folder named libiers10++-1.0. Change into the newly created directory: bash$ cd libiers10++-1.0
Run configure script to prepare the installation: bash$ ./configure
Run make: bash$ make
And finally, : bash$ sudo make install
You will need root privileges for this last command (hence the sudo).
That should be all! Check for details on verifying the installation.

section.title: Test Suits
section.para: The package includes source files for testing the installation and/or implementation of the libiers software. You can only perform the tests, after a successeful installation. Two source code files, namely test/test.cpp and test/test-hardisp.cpp provide easy-to-built test cases.

The files test/test.cpp implements a number of tests, using all but one functions (hardisp) of the library. To build this file, change into the test/ directory, and type: bash$ make test This will (hopefully) result in an executable file, named test in the test directory.
You can execute this program and see the results. It should output the differences compared to the test cases provided in the original FORTRAN source code files. More information can be found at .

The source code file test/test-hardisp.cpp is an implementation of the hardisp function. The version of the function implemented here though, differs from the original, as it is not a stand-alone program, but a pure function, used as any other in this library. The user can specify an input file and a set of input parameters and deploy the function.

To build this test suite, change into the test directory and execute: bash$ make test-hardisp This should result in a new executable file called test-hardisp (in the test directory). To run this, you must provide a file containing the required coefficients. Such a file, is e.g. test/onsa.blq and test/reyk.blq.

section.title: Building The Documentation
section.para: The Project's documentation is NOT build by default (i.e. when invoking make). The reason for this, is that the build process (for the documentation) is based on external tools that may or may not de present on the target system. Hence, the process could easily fail and force the installation process to stop, or confuse users regarding the installation status.

The documentation for the Project, is build using two seperate tools, namely Doxygen and DocBook. Doxygen is a cross-platform documentation generator published under GNUGPL. This tool is used to create an API for the library and some man pages.

DocBook is used to create the reference manual (what you are actually reading) in html and pdf format. It is not a 'tool' per se, but depends on a toolchain of tools. To build the aforementioned files, you will need:
xsltproc, which is an XML parser and toolkit
fop, which is an print formatter driven by XSL formatting objects (XSL-FO) and an output independent formatter
DocBook Stylesheets, which are stylesheets to control the output
If you are not interested in installing the reference guide, there is no need to install/use any of the tools above. After all, you can download or see the reference guide online at Dionysos Satellite Observatory.

There are several build targets, depending on what you are interesting in:
api_html: uses Doxygen to create a library API in html format.
api_man : uses Doxygen to create a library man pages.
ref_guide_html : uses xsltproc and a valid stylesheet to create (this) reference guide in html format.
ref_guide_pdf: uses xsltproc, fop and a valid stylesheet to create (this) reference guide in pdf format.
doc: build all the above.
Change into the doc/ directory to build whatever target you need, using: bash$ make TARGET
